                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">The Linguistics Enrichment Experience Program (LEEP)</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none"></span>OVERVIEW</h2>
<h3><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none"></span><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none">What is LEEP?</span></h3>
<p>A <strong>Linguistic Enrichment Experience</strong> is a course or organized activity outside the requirements for the major (core + elective courses) that enables and requires the student to apply linguistic skills and knowledge gained in the major in a novel, productive and synergistic way.  This includes research, creation of linguistic materials for specific purposes (e.g. language teaching or language revitalization), community engagement, and internships.<br><em></em></p>
<h2>QUALIFICATION FOR LEEP</h2>
<h3><em></em><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none"></span><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none">What Courses, Internships or Activities Qualify as LEEP?</span></h3>
<ul><li>Ling 199 (Supervised Independent Study)</li>
<li>Ling 199 (Senior Paper)</li>
<li>Ling 198 (Directed Group Study)</li>
<li>Ling 197 (<a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/ugrad/lrap" rel="noreferrer">LRAP</a>) The Linguistics Research Apprentice Practicum</li>
<li><a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-program/sawyer-scholarship-applied-linguistics" rel="noreferrer">The Sawyer Scholarship</a></li>
<li><a href="http://urap.berkeley.edu/" rel="noreferrer">URAP </a>(Undergraduate Research Apprentice Program)</li>
<li>Off Campus Linguistics Related Internships (subject to approval by Undergraduate Advisors)</li>
<li>Other (subject to approval by Undergraduate Advisors)</li>
</ul><h2>ADMINISTRATIVE IMPLEMENTATION</h2>
<h3><span style="color:#000000; text-decoration:none"><strong>How Do We Record and Acknowledge Participation </strong><strong>of LEEP</strong><strong>?</strong><br></span></h3>
<ul><li>Graduating seniors of Fall, Spring and Summer terms will be sent a LEEP Questionnaire.</li>
<li>Based on the response from the questionnaire, students will be notified by the department of their qualification.</li>
<li>All LEEP activities will be recorded and recognized by the department in the form of an individualized diploma that identifies the experience (coursework, internship or activity).</li>
<li>The diploma will be distributed upon graduation at a departmental reception (Spring Semester).</li>
</ul><p></p>
<p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

        <h2 class="block__title"><a href="/academics" class="active-trail">Academics</a></h2>
    
  <div class="block__content">

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Sawyer Scholarship for Applied Linguistics</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>What is the Sawyer Scholarship?</h2>
<p>The Department of Linguistics is excited to offer a new scholarship, the Sawyer Scholarship for Applied Linguistics, to be awarded for the first time for the summer of 2017.</p>
<p>The Sawyer scholarship is awarded to a UC Berkeley undergraduate student to pursue a summer project or activity within any area of applied linguistics. This could be a research project, an internship, engagement with language teaching or learning, development of language teaching or learning materials, shadowing of a professional in the applicant’s intended career path, or some other applied linguistics project. We anticipate that the scholarship amount will be $2500-$4000.</p>
<h2>Eligibility</h2>
<p><strong>All majors and class standing may apply if you meet all of the following:</strong></p>
<ul><li>You are an undergraduate student currently enrolled at UC Berkeley.</li>
<li>You are in good academic standing with a <strong>minimum 2.0 GPA</strong> at UC Berkeley.</li>
<li>Your project falls within applied linguistics (if in doubt talk to your project sponsor).</li>
</ul><h2>Application guidelines and process</h2>
<p><strong>Your application should include:</strong></p>
<ol><li>Your name and transcript of your UC Berkeley course work (transcript can be a screen shot, <span>no official transcript required).</span></li>
<li>A brief description (up to 1 page) of <strong>what</strong> project or activity you intend to pursue.</li>
<li>A brief statement (up to 1 page) explaining <strong>why</strong> you would like to do this project or activity, <span>including the goals of the project or activity and how they fit with your larger educational </span><span>and/or career goals, and your preparation for doing the project or activity, including course </span><span>work, personal background, work experience (volunteer or paid).</span></li>
<li>Name, affiliation, and contact information of <strong>project sponsor</strong>. The project sponsor can be a <span>linguistics faculty member, a faculty member from another department or another educational </span><span>institution, or an off-campus professional or specialist.</span></li>
</ol><p>Submit your application by email with the subject line "Sawyer Scholarship 2017" to <strong>Martine Alexander</strong> (<a href="mailto:martinea@berkeley.edu" rel="noreferrer">martinea@berkeley.edu</a>) by <strong>March 1, 2017</strong>. </p>
<p>Applicants will be notified by March 25th.</p>
<p>If you have questions, please contact the Undergraduate Staff Advisor, Martine Alexander, at <a href="mailto:martinea@berkeley.edu" rel="noreferrer">martinea@berkeley.edu</a> .</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">SLUgS</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img alt="Banner for SLUgS" title="Banner for SLUgS" src="https://lx.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/styles/panopoly_image_original/public/slugs_banner.png?itok=LOfEbOqw&amp;timestamp=1472076739"></p>
<p><span>The <a href="https://slugs.berkeley.edu/" rel="noreferrer">Society of Linguistics Undergraduate Students</a> is a student-run organization that hosts weekly academic and social activities for lovers of linguistics. Past events include a talk from David J. Peterson, creator of Dothraki from <em>Game of Thrones</em>, a monolingual elicitation, palatography, tours of the PhonLab, and sponsorship of a regional Esperanto conference. We try our best to provide a space for linguistics students outside the classroom setting, both to create connections and foster discussion about linguistics itself and about the degree and its applicability. Membership is open to anyone interested!</span></p>
<h3><span><span>Staying connected</span></span></h3>
<p><span style="color:#333333">Follow us on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/calslugs/" rel="noreferrer">Facebook</a>.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333333">Website: <a href="https://slugs.berkeley.edu/" rel="noreferrer">Society of Linguistics Undergraduate Students</a><br></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333333"></span><span>Contact us at <a href="mailto:calslugs@gmail.com" rel="noreferrer">calslugs@gmail.com</a>.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>

<p><a href="https://berkeley.box.com/s/47s3ajaj46gq4fdzzw4ukdv2fvbwzlhb" rel="noreferrer">Why major in linguistics (and what does a linguist do)?</a> The Linguistic Society of America answers these commonly-asked questions.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Visiting Scholars Program</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Visiting Scholars Program requires:</p>
<ol><li><span>That the Visiting Scholar provide his or her funding and provide proof thereof. The minimum funding level permitted by the program is $2000 per month (plus $650 per month if accompanied by spouse and $350 per month per child if accompanied by children). Note: $2500-$3000/month is recommended for an individual.</span></li>
<li><span></span>That the Visiting Scholar have a <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/people/faculty"><span style="color:#0066cc">faculty</span></a> sponsor from this department.</li>
<li>Evidence of English Language Proficiency</li>
<li>That the Visiting Scholar have adequate health insurance coverage for himself or herself and any dependents during their stay.</li>
</ol><p>Please contact <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/people/department-staff"><span style="color:#0066cc">Belén Flores</span></a> for further information.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Berkeley Field Methods Courses</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-12">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Berkeley Field Methods courses for the last two decades are listed below. Linguistics 240AB is the graduate Field Methods course; Linguistics 140 is Introduction to Field Methods, for undergraduates. </p>
<table><tbody><tr><td><strong>Year</strong></td>
<td><strong>Instructor</strong></td>

</tr><tr><td>2016-17</td>

<td>South Bolivian Quechua</td>
</tr><tr><td>F 2016</td>
<td>Larry M. Hyman</td>

</tr><tr><td>Sp 2016</td>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Christine Beier: Current Courses</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-12">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>Fall 2017. Linguistics 154: Language Revitalization: Theory and Practice</strong></p>
<p>This course explores a range of theories and practices that undergird efforts by linguists and language activists to revitalize and revalorize endangered languages in communities around the world, with a focus on the Americas. Beginning with an exploration of how linguistic diversity, language vitality, and language politics interact, the course will narrow focus toward individual student projects that explore language revitalization issues in the context of a specific language or community, including the option to create usable revitalization materials for that community.</p>
<p>It is simultaneously true that individual languages become endangered for reasons that are rooted in their specific social, historical, and political contexts; and that large-scale patterns and causes of language endangerment can be identified and therefore redressed. If, in a given language community, language revitalization is a desired objective, then a clear understanding of the specific factors that led to endangerment can make the difference between success and failure in revitalization work.</p>
<p>This course takes a holistic view of the question of language vitality, approaching it as both a linguistic and a social phenomenon. Therefore, we will draw on a range of relevant perspectives -- from linguistics and language documentation to linguistic, social, and activist anthropology. Similarly, we will examine language endangerment and revitalization as experienced in non-westernized contexts along with westernized ones.</p>
<p><span> </span></p>
<p><strong> </strong></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

    <p><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/bls/" rel="noreferrer">BLS</a> <br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/cognetwork/" rel="noreferrer">CogNetwork</a><br><a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/dhworom">*dhworom</a><br><a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/fieldwork-forum-fforum" rel="noreferrer">Fieldwork Forum</a> <br><a href="http://lclab.berkeley.edu/" rel="noreferrer">Language and Cognition Lab</a><br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~phorum/" rel="noreferrer">Phonetics and Phonology Forum</a><br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/phonlab/" rel="noreferrer">PhonLab</a><br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/sei/index.html" rel="noreferrer">Script Encoding Initiative</a><br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/Survey/" rel="noreferrer">Survey of California and Other Indian Languages</a><br><a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~syntax-circle/" rel="noreferrer">Syntax &amp; Semantics Circle</a><br><br></p>

                  <div id="breadcrumb" class="visible-desktop">
            <h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><div class="item-list"><ul class="breadcrumb"><li class="first"><a href="/home">Home</a></li>
<li class="last">Early Berkeley Linguistics Courses</li>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Early Berkeley Linguistics Courses</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-12">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>From 1901-02 through 1905-06, according to University of California publications, courses under the heading Linguistics were taught at UC. They are listed below, together with the general linguistics course offerings in Anthropology (which began in 1903-04). After the 1905-06 academic year, general linguistics courses were taught in Anthropology until the late 1910s. (Note that the modern convention whereby numbers below 100 designate lower-division courses was not yet in effect; some of these courses were for graduate students and none were for lower-division students.)</p>
<table><tbody><tr><td style="width:80px">1901-02</td>
<td>Linguistics 1: General Introduction to the Science of Language</td>
<td>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Linguistics 2: Indo-European Comparative Grammar</td>
<td><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Linguistics 3: The Relationship of the Indo-European, Semitic, and Egyptian Families of Languages</td>
<td>Max L. Margolis</td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Linguistics 4: Elementary Sanskrit</td>
<td>T. Stanley Simonds</td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px">1902-03</td>
<td><span>Linguistics 1: General Introduction to the Science of Language</span></td>
<td><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Linguistics 2: Indo-European Comparative Grammar</span></td>
<td><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Linguistics 5: Fundamental Problems of Linguistics</td>
<td>Max L. Margolis</td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px">1903-04</td>
<td><span>Linguistics 1: General Introduction to the Science of Language</span></td>
<td><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Anthropology 3: North American Languages</td>
<td><span>A. L. Kroeber</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td>Anthropology 6: Experimental Phonetics</td>
<td><span>Pliny Earle Goddard</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px">1904-05</td>
<td><span>Linguistics 1: General Introduction to the Science of Language</span></td>
<td><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Anthropology 3AB: North American Languages</span></td>
<td><span>A. L. Kroeber</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Anthropology 6AB: Experimental Phonetics</span></td>
<td><span>Pliny Earle Goddard</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"><span>1905-06</span></td>
<td><span><span><span><span>Linguistics 1: <span>General Introduction to the Science of Language</span></span></span></span></span></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></span></span></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span>Linguistics 2: Indo-European Comparative Grammar</span></span></span></span></span></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span>Benjamin Ide Wheeler</span></span></span></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span>Linguistics 4: Elementary Sanskrit</span></span></span></span></span></td>
<td><span><span><span><span>Herbert Nutting</span></span></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span><span>Anthropology 6A: Experimental Phonetics</span></span></span></span></span></span></td>
<td><span><span><span><span><span>Pliny Earle Goddard</span></span></span></span></span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Anthropology 3A: North American Languages</span></td>
<td><span>A. L. Kroeber</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Anthropology 12: The Determination of Linguistic Relationship</span></td>
<td><span>A. L. Kroeber</span></td>
</tr><tr><td style="width:80px"></td>
<td><span>Anthropology 8: Advanced Work in Primitive Languages</span></td>
<td><span>A. L. Kroeber</span></td>
</tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>

  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h3>Lower-Division Courses</h3>
<ul><li>1A. American Sign Language I. Sherry Hicks. Section I.</li>
<li>1A. <span>American Sign Language I. Sherry Hicks. Section II.</span></li>
<li>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies. Section I: TuTh 9:30-11.</li>
<li>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies. Section II: TuTh 3:30-5.</li>
<li>5. Language and Linguistics. <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/richard-rhodes" rel="noreferrer">Richard A. Rhodes</a>. MWF 10-11.</li>
<li>24. Voices of Berkeley: Everybody Has an Accent (freshman seminar, section I)<span><span><span>. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~susanlin/index.php" rel="noreferrer">Susan Lin</a>. </span></span></span>W 3-4.</li>
<li>24. One State, Many Voices: Linguistic Diversity in California (f<span><span>reshman sem</span></span>inar, section II). <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~mikkelsen/" rel="noreferrer">Line Mikkelsen</a>. Tu 1-2.</li>
<li>40. Language of Advertising. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~sweetser/" rel="noreferrer">Eve Sweetser</a>. TuTh 9:30-11.</li>
<li>C70. Working with Grammar: Linguistic Tools for Learning and Teaching a Native American Language. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~mikkelsen/" rel="noreferrer">Line Mikkelsen</a>. TuTh 11-12:30.</li>
</ul><h3>Upper-Division Courses</h3>
<ul><li><span>100. <span>Introduction to Linguistic Science. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~jenks/" rel="noreferrer">Peter Jenks</a>. MWF 1-2.</span></span></li>
<li><span><span>108. Introduction to Psycholinguistics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~gahl/" rel="noreferrer">Susanne Gahl</a>. TuTh 3:30-5.</span></span></li>
<li><span><span>110. <span>Introduction to Phonetics and Phonology. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~susanlin/index.php" rel="noreferrer">Susan Lin</a>. MWF 2-3.</span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span>121. Logical Semantics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~ardeal/" rel="noreferrer">Amy Rose Deal</a>. MWF 1-2.</span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span>123. Pragmatics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~sweetser/" rel="noreferrer">Eve Sweetser</a>. TuTh 12:30-2.</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span>130. <span>Comparative and Historical Linguistics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~garrett/" rel="noreferrer">Andrew Garrett</a>. MWF 11-12.</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span>150. Sociolinguistics. Brian Smith. TuTh 9:30-11.</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span><span><span>154. <span>Language Revitalization: Theory and Practice. <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/christine-beier" rel="noreferrer">Christine Beier</a>. MWF 10-11.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul><h3>Graduate Courses</h3>
<ul><li><span>200. <span>Graduate Proseminar in Linguistics.<span><span> <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~gahl/" rel="noreferrer">Susanne Gahl</a>. </span></span>Th 11-12.<br></span></span></li>
<li><span><span>201. <span>Advanced Graduate Proseminar in Linguistics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~garrett/" rel="noreferrer">Andrew Garrett</a>. F 9-11.<br></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span>211B. <span>Topics in Phonological Theory. Brian Smith. TuTh 2-3:30.<br></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span>220A. <span>Syntax and Semantics 1. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~jenks/" rel="noreferrer">Peter Jenks</a>. MW 10:30-12.<br></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span><span>221. Advanced Logical Semantics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~ardeal/" rel="noreferrer">Amy Rose Deal</a>. MW 9-10:30.</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span><span>240A. <span>Field Methods. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~levmichael/home.html" rel="noreferrer">Lev Michael</a>. TuTh 9:30-11.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span><span><span><span><span>375. Training for Linguistics Teaching Assistants. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~inkelas/" rel="noreferrer">Sharon Inkelas</a><span>.</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

                  <div id="breadcrumb" class="visible-desktop">
            <h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><div class="item-list"><ul class="breadcrumb"><li class="first"><a href="/" title="Linguistics">Home</a></li>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Frequently Asked Questions - Graduate Program</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    <div class="faq-content"><div class="faq"><div class="faq-category-group openberkeley-faq-hide-answer">
  <!-- category header with title, link, image, description, and count of
  questions inside -->
  <div class="faq-qa-header">
        
      </div> <!-- Close div: faq-qa-header -->

  
  <div class="faq-qa">

  <!-- list questions (in title link) and answers (in body) -->
  <div class="faq-dl-hide-answer">
            <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n67" class="active">I already have an advanced degree. What is the policy on duplicate degrees?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>UC Berkeley, in general, will not grant a second degree to someone holding an advanced degree in the same field. But, students who already hold an M.A. degree from another institution in Linguistics, or any field, and are admitted into the Linguistics Ph.D. program at Berkeley, will be granted a second M.A. upon completion of the M.A. requirements. Students who are enrolled in a Ph.D. program in Linguistics elsewhere at the time they apply to U.C. Berkeley will not be allowed to transfer Ph.D. units. If the Department of Linguistics or the Graduate Division determines from information provided on the application that a student will obtain a Linguistics-related Ph.D. degree before the date that he/she would enter our graduate program, the application will not be processed. Though the University wishes to discourage students who already hold a Ph.D. in an unrelated subject from enrolling in the Ph.D. program in Linguistics, we can petition for an exception to this policy.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n66" class="active">What opportunities are there for exchange programs with other institutions?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students enrolled at any University of California campus may take courses at another UC campus for credit to be applied to their home department's degree program. Students interested in this option should talk to their own department, as well as to the faculty members in our department who would be teaching the courses that are of interest to them. An application form for the Intercampus Exchange Program may be obtained from Graduate Services, 318 Sproul Hall, (510) 642-7330. Students who have maintained good standing at UC Berkeley or at Stanford University for a year of graduate study may apply to take courses through the Stanford-California Exchange Program. Doctoral students who have completed one year of studies at Berkeley are also eligible to participate in the Exchange Scholar Program which allows them to study at Brown, Chicago, Columbia, Cornell, Harvard, MIT, Princeton, Stanford or Yale for up to one year. More information on this program can also be obtained through Graduate Division. Graduate students who have completed at least one year at UC Berkeley may be granted permission to study abroad at most of the study centers under the Education Abroad Program. (Linguistics students are encouraged to apply for Foreign Language Area Study (FLAS) fellowships for the summer or the regular academic year in order to secure funding for foreign language study at home or abroad.) For more information on the Education Abroad Program write to: Berkeley Programs for Study Abroad, 160 Stephens Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720-2302, (510) 642-1356 or (510) 642-1790.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n65" class="active">Is the Berkeley graduate program a good fit for me if I am interested in language teaching or translation?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students whose primary interest is in the field of Applied Linguistics, especially the Teaching of English as a Second Language (TESOL or ESL) should be aware that there is no faculty specialization in this area at UC Berkeley and very little relevant coursework offered in the Department of Linguistics. (Note, however, there are some courses offered through the Education Department's Language and Literacy Program.) Linguistic programs with specialization in TESOL and other areas of Applied Linguistics are San Jose State University (San Jose, CA 94192), the University of California, Los Angeles (Los Angeles, CA 90024), San Francisco State University (San Francisco, CA 94132), the University of Michigan (Ann Arbor, MI 48109), Ohio University (Athens, OH 45701-2979), Georgetown University (Washington, D.C. 20057), and Southern Illinois University (Carbondale, IL 62901).</p>
<p>Students whose primary interest is in the field of language translation should consider the programs at Georgetown University (Washington, D.C. 20057) and at the Monterey Institute of Foreign Studies (Monterey, CA 93940). If you wish to obtain information on other programs in Linguistics in the United States and Canada you can access the Linguistic Society of America's (LSA) web site. Questions regarding the LSA Directory of Programs in Linguistics may be addressed to LSA Secretariat, <a href="mailto:lsa@lsadc.org" rel="noreferrer">lsa@lsadc.org</a>.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n63" class="active">How do I choose a field of study?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students should choose whether or not to apply to UC Berkeley Linguistics carefully, making sure that their interests overlap to a significant degree with the expectations of the program. Having fulfilled the requirements for the M.A. in Linguistics students have more flexibility in choice of classes, since there are few additional course requirements beyond the M.A. program in our department. To have recognition for breadth of interests, it is possible to take a second M.A. in another department before proceeding to a Ph.D. Another option would be to design a unique course of study. Such an option is only available to students with a superior academic record who have completed at least two semesters of a doctoral program at UC Berkeley, working with faculty members from several departments to create an individual program, which then must meet with the approval of the Dean of the Graduate Division. It is not possible to be admitted to UC Berkeley as an "unaffiliated student". Students must first be admitted into and show success in a particular program before designing a unique course of study. It is possible, however, for a person who has not been accepted into a graduate program to take individual courses of interest. (See the section on Concurrent Enrollment.)</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n64" class="active">How do I get credit for outside work?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students who have completed coursework relevant to our program at another institution may be allowed to apply that work toward a degree at UC Berkeley. This can be accomplished in one of two ways: either by formal transfer of credit or by waiver of requirements. After the first semester of residence at UC Berkeley a graduate student may transfer up to 4 semester units or 6 quarter units toward the M.A. program in the Department of Linguistics. This lowers the number of units necessary to complete the degree, but it does not automatically fulfill any other departmental requirements. Alternatively, work can be applied toward an M.A. at UC Berkeley through a waiver of requirements. In certain cases a required course may be waived if a student has previously completed coursework that is comparable to the corresponding course at Berkeley. Such a waiver requires the permission of the professor who normally teaches the course, as well as that of the Head Graduate Advisor. Unlike a transfer of units, this waiver will not decrease the total units of UC Berkeley coursework required for the M.A. degree. It may, however, allow the student to take more advanced courses and enable the student to receive the degree sooner.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n62" class="active">Can I take courses without being admitted to the program?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Even if you are not enrolled in an academic department at UC Berkeley, it is possible to take many of the Linguistics courses that are offered to Berkeley students through Concurrent Enrollment, a program that is under the auspices of UC Extension. Taking Linguistics courses through this program does not imply that you have been or will be accepted into the Department of Linguistics' graduate program. If you are later accepted into the program you would not be able to transfer courses you have taken under Concurrent Enrollment towards the course load required for an M.A. degree, though it would allow you to skip certain prerequisite courses in order to take more specialized courses during the M.A. program. One advantage of taking courses through Concurrent Enrollment is that you might become more familiar with the faculty members and have a better idea of the focus of our program. For further information, contact the UC Extension Office, 1995 University Avenue, Suite #110, Berkeley, CA 94720-7000; (510) 642-4111.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
          <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
      <h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller">
      <span datatype="" property="dc:title"><a href="/faq/graduate-program" id="t11n61" class="active">Can I do coursework in the summer?</a></span>      </h4> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->

      <div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
      <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>No courses required for the Linguistics M.A. are offered in the summer, only introductory undergrad linguistics courses can be taken. To obtain more information and to register for classes contact the Summer Sessions Office, 1995 University Avenue, Suite #1080, Berkeley, CA 94720-1080, (510) 642-5611. All students are encouraged to participate in one or more of the Linguistic Institutes sponsored every other summer by the Linguistic Society of America (LSA). Each Linguistic Institute features a wide range of courses, seminars, conferences, workshops, and lectures covering developments in Linguistics and related fields; Berkeley graduate students and faculty often participate. Scholarships are available from the LSA and possibly (depending on funding) from the Berkeley Department of Linguistics. For more information, write to the LSA, 1325 18th Street, NW, Suite 211, Washington, DC 20036-6501, fax (202) 835-1714, email: <a href="mailto:lsa@lsadc.org" rel="noreferrer">lsa@lsadc.org<span><span class="element-invisible">(link sends e-mail)</span></span></a> or check their <a href="http://www.linguisticsociety.org/" rel="noreferrer"><span>website</span><span><span><span class="element-invisible">(link is external)</span></span></span></a>.</p></div></div></div>                          </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target -->
      </div> <!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
      
  <!-- include subcategories -->
    </div> <!-- Close div: faq-dl-hide-answer -->

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Applying to the Graduate Program</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><ul><li>
<pre>Application deadline: <strong>extended to </strong><strong>December 2, 2017, </strong><strong>8:59pm PST</strong> due to system error. (strict)</pre>
</li>
</ul><ul><li>Use the <a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">On-line application form</a> - available as of September 2017.</li>
<li>Application materials - (upload with application)
<ul><li>Letters of recommendation</li>
<li>Transcripts of courses taken</li>
<li>Writing sample</li>
<li>Admissions essays - particularly the "Statement of Purpose"</li>
<li>GRE is not required (please do not submit GRE scores)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>International students
<ul><li>Take the TOEFL English Proficiency test by October, 2017.</li>
<li>Translate application materials documents (particularly the transcripts)</li>
</ul></li>
<li>What we look for -- Our main question is, "Will you be successful at Berkeley?" We look for evidence in:
<ul><li>Letters of recommendation - from people who know both you and us - predicting that you will be successful in this program.</li>
<li>Good grades in hard courses and in relevant courses</li>
<li>A well-focussed, mature statement of purpose that answers "why linguistics?" and "why Berkeley?"</li>
<li>A strong writing sample, preferably relevant to your aims in our program.</li>
<li>A BA in Linguistics or a relevant allied discipline</li>
</ul></li>
</ul><hr><h3>Some Details</h3>
<p>Additional instructions for completing the on-line "Graduate Application for Admissions and Fellowships" can be found at the <a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Graduate Division's admissions</a> website. Note: applicants are responsible for reading and complying with all application guidelines. Below are further details about a few important aspects of the admissions application.</p>
<p><strong>Admissions Essays</strong>: Your statement of purpose should: 1. Include the names of the <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/people/faculty" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">faculty members</a> whose research seems to match your own interests, and briefly discuss the connections you see. Please also provide this information where requested on the on-line application. 2. Describe your relevant research experience, and note any publications you have authored or co-authored. Here is some helpful advice about writing <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/apply/statement-purpose/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">the statement of purpose</a> and the <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/apply/personal-statement/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">personal statement</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Letters of Recommendation</strong>: Three letters of recommendation are required. You will be asked to submit the names of your recommenders and valid email addresses as part of the on-line application. The admissions system will contact them directly, and you will be able to check whether their letters have been added to the application. Please give your recommenders plenty of advanced notification for submitting their letters so that they may be submitted by the deadline.</p>
<p><strong>Transcripts</strong>: Copies of all relevant official transcripts from all university/college level institutions attended (this requirement applies to both domestic and international applicants) must be submitted/uploaded with your on-line Graduate Application for Admissions and Fellowships. Transcripts in a language other than English must be accompanied by official English translations, as described in the "International Applicants" section of <a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/requirements/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">the Graduate Division's Admissions Requirements</a>. Note: Submission of official/sealed transcripts will only be required if you are admitted to the program and you accept the offer of admission.</p>
<p><strong>English Proficiency</strong>: All applicants from countries in which the official language is not English are required to submit official evidence of English language proficiency. See the <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/requirements" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">admissions requirements</a> web page for details.</p>
<p><strong>Writing Sample</strong>: A writing sample is required of all applicants. Ideally, this sample would be a research paper on a linguistic topic, but it should in any event demonstrate the applicant's competence in writing analytic expository prose. The writing sample is to be submitted/uploaded with your on-line application.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Funding</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Department strives to provide funding for every graduate student. Particular effort in recent years has gone to putting together multi-year (usually 5-year) funding packages for newly admitted students, although this is not always possible. Funding can take a variety of forms, both internal and extramural, including:</p>
<ul><li>multi-year university fellowships (available only at admission, by departmental nomination)</li>
<li>multi-year external US government fellowships (e.g. NSF, Javits). Domestic applicants are strongly encouraged to apply for these when applying to graduate school.</li>
<li>FLAS (Foreign Language Area Studies) fellowships, to support students studying a particular language</li>
<li>other specialized external grants</li>
<li>dissertation year fellowships (external and internal)</li>
<li>departmental stipends for the academic year and/or summer research</li>
<li>support for organzing or traveling to conferences</li>
<li>Graduate Student Researcher (GSR) positions in Linguistics or other departments (normally for continuing students only)</li>
<li>Graduate Student Instructor (GSI) positions in Linguistics or other departments (normally for continuing students only)</li>
</ul><p>The ideal funding package is a 5-year combination of fellowship support and teaching, which many students augment with 6th year dissertation fellowships; this combination provides students both with the opportunity to do fulltime coursework and research and with the opportunity to gain teaching experience. The experience of teaching is invaluable in a student's own training in linguistics; it is also essential in the post-Ph.D. competition for academic positions, a competition in which Berkeley Ph.D.s typically excel, due to the depth and breadth of their graduate training.</p>
<p>The <a href="http://www.grad.berkeley.edu/financial/deadlines.shtml" rel="noreferrer"><span style="color:#0066cc">Graduate Division fellowships website</span></a> has a helpful and comprehensive list of fellowships and other funding opportunities available to new and continuing graduate students. Information in a much briefer form is provided in the Graduate Division's flyer on graduate study. Financial aid, for other forms of aid available to students, including loans, see <a href="http://financialaid.berkeley.edu/explore-types-aid" rel="noreferrer">Berkeley Financial Aid &amp; Scholarships.</a></p>
<p>All domestic students applying for any kind of university fellowships, departmental awards or financial aid must submit the <a href="http://www.fafsa.ed.gov/" rel="noreferrer"><span style="color:#0066cc">Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA)</span></a>, usually due at the beginning of March.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Graduate Program</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h3>The Berkeley Linguistics Graduate Program</h3>
<ul><li>5 or 6 year, full-time Ph.D. program (no M.A. admissions).</li>
<li>Admissions is competitive - only about 10% of all applicants are offered admissions.</li>
<li>There is one admissions cycle per year (apply in the fall (Dec. 1 deadline) to start the following August).</li>
<li>The aim of the training program is to lead you to a career in research and/or teaching.</li>
</ul><h3>Outline of a graduate career in Berkeley Linguistics</h3>
<ul><li><span style="text-decoration:underline">Year 1</span>. Foundation coursework in 5 key areas of linguistics (Phonology, Syntax, Historical Linguistics, Language &amp; Cognition, Language &amp; Society). Capped by the M.A. oral exam.</li>
<li><span style="text-decoration:underline">Year 2</span>. Research training I - elective advanced coursework on topics of interest, and methods training. Capped by Qualifying Paper 1.</li>
<li><span style="text-decoration:underline">Year 3</span>. Research training II - more elective courses and close work with adviser. Capped by Qualifying Paper 2 and the Qualifying Exam.</li>
<li><span style="text-decoration:underline">Years 4 &amp; 5 (&amp; 6)</span>. Ph.D. dissertation years. Close work with the dissertation committee. The period opens with the defense of your dissertation prospectus and is capped by filing your Ph.D. dissertation.</li>
</ul><h3>Detailed description</h3>
<p>The particulars of this program, describing the exact course requirements, details about the exams and required research papers are available in the <a href="https://berkeley.box.com/s/kaosqmn07cl3mtt9v90nfu2ip5qndqca" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Linguistics Graduate Program description</a>. This document changes from year to year. Get previous versions of the program description for <a href="https://berkeley.box.com/s/dnb5za7dgq7vs32v3nmad0p6hqtn81io" rel="noreferrer">2016</a>, <a href="https://berkeley.box.com/s/fxyhol7p1htusr60lk5o84332ver8crb" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">2015</a> and <a href="https://berkeley.box.com/s/xr8wsz56s2c32ayuteafp43fsmn7yslq" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">2014.</a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
<div class="panel-pane pane-fieldable-panels-pane pane-uuid-1c47ca58-1ea6-4308-8d30-b7ed5b6b7e44 pane-bundle-text clearfix"  >
  
        <h2 class="pane-title">
      Student Services Mission Statement    </h2>
    
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="fieldable-panels-pane">
    <div class="field field-name-field-basic-text-text field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Student Services Unit of the Department of Linguistics guides and supports students in achieving their academic, career, and personal goals by providing personalized, comprehensive advising and by facilitating activities and opportunities that enhance and encourage student success.  The dedicated, professional staff strives to provide excellent service to prospective and current students, faculty, alumni, and university colleagues.  While upholding University and Departmental policies, the staff focuses on student needs, respecting differences and appreciating commonalities, and endeavors to work efficiently and effectively to continually improve the services and programs that are offered.</p></div></div></div></div>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h3>Lower-Division Courses</h3>
<ul><li>1B. American Sign Language II. Sherry Hicks. Section I.</li>
<li>1B. American Sign Language II. Sherry Hicks. Section II.</li>
<li>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~csandy/Site/Home.html" rel="noreferrer">Clare Sandy</a>. Section I. TuTh 9:30-11, 106 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~edonnelly/" rel="noreferrer">Erin Donnelly</a>. Section II. TuTh 3:30-5, 31 Evans.</li>
<li>5. Language and Linguistics. <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/richard-rhodes" rel="noreferrer">Richard A. Rhodes</a>. MWF 10-11, 20 Barrows.</li>
<li>10. The Sounds of English. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~kjohnson/" rel="noreferrer">Keith Johnson</a>. MWF 1-2, 370 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>24. Freshman Seminar: Language Myths. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~hyman/" rel="noreferrer">Larry M. Hyman</a>. W 11-12, 134 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>47. Language and Communication Disorders. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~gahl/" rel="noreferrer">Susanne Gahl</a>. TuTh 11-12:30, 240 Mulford.</li>
</ul><h3>Upper-Division Courses</h3>
<ul><li>100. Introduction to Linguistic Science. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~garrett/index.html" rel="noreferrer">Andrew Garrett</a>. MWF 1-2, A1 Hearst Field Annex.</li>
<li>108. Introduction to Psycholinguistics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~gahl/" rel="noreferrer">Susanne Gahl</a>. TuTh 3:30-5, 254 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>113. Experimental Phonetics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~susanlin/index.php" rel="noreferrer">Susan Lin</a>. TuTh 11-12:30, 254 Sutardja Dai.</li>
<li>115. Phonology and Morphology. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~hyman/" rel="noreferrer">Larry M. Hyman</a><span>. MWF 1-2, 160 Kroeber.<br></span></li>
<li>120. Introduction to Syntax and Semantics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~jenks/" rel="noreferrer">Peter Jenks</a>. MWF 10-11, 106 Stanley.</li>
<li>121. Logical Semantics<span>. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~mikkelsen/" rel="noreferrer">Line Mikkelsen</a>. TuTh 9:30-11, 215 Dwinelle.<br></span></li>
<li>C142. Language and Thought. <a href="http://lclab.berkeley.edu/regier/" rel="noreferrer">Terry Regier</a>. W 2-4, F 2-3, 88 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>C146. Language Acquisition. <a href="http://psychology.berkeley.edu/people/mahesh-srinivasan" rel="noreferrer">Mahesh Srinivasan</a>. MW 2-3, 100 GPB.</li>
<li>C160. Quantitative Methods in Linguistics. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~kjohnson/" rel="noreferrer">Keith Johnson</a>. MWF 9-10, 370 Dwinelle.</li>
</ul><h3>Graduate Courses</h3>
<ul><li><span>211A. Advanced</span><span> Phonological Theory. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~inkelas/" rel="noreferrer">Sharon Inkelas</a>. TuTh 2-3:30, 1303 Dwinelle.<br></span></li>
<li>220B. Syntax and Semantics II. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~mikkelsen/" rel="noreferrer">Line Mikkelsen</a>. TuTh 12:30-2, 1303 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>230. Historical Linguistics. <a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/gary-holland" rel="noreferrer">Gary Holland</a>. TuTh 11-12:30, 1303 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>240B. Field Methods. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~levmichael/home.html" rel="noreferrer">Lev Michael</a>. F 11-12, 1303 Dwinelle; 3:30-5, 1226 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>243. Language, Computation, and Cognition. <a href="http://lclab.berkeley.edu/regier/" rel="noreferrer">Terry Regier</a>. W 9-12, 1303 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>290E. Topics in Linguistic Theory: Grammatical Aspects of Tone. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~hyman/" rel="noreferrer">Larry M. Hyman</a>. WF 3:30-5, 1303 Dwinelle.</li>
<li>290E. Topics in Linguistic Theory: Gestural Timing. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~susanlin/index.php" rel="noreferrer">Susan Lin</a>. TuTh 3:30-5, 1303 Dwinelle.</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

              <h1 class="title">Summer 2017 Courses</h1>
            </div>

        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h3>Session A (May 22-June 30)</h3>
<ul><li>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies<span>. MTuWTh 10-12. 4 units.<br></span></li>
<li><span><span>100. <span>Introduction to Linguistic Science. MTuWTh 12-2.</span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span>151. Language and Gender. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~edonnelly/" rel="noreferrer">Erin Donnelly</a>. MTuWTh 9-11.</span></span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span>183. The Linguistics of <em>Game of Thrones</em> and the Art of Language Invention. <a href="http://www.artoflanguageinvention.com/" rel="noreferrer">David J. Peterson</a>. MTuWTh 3-5.</span></span></span></li>
</ul><h3>Session C (June 19-August 11)</h3>
<ul><li><span><span>C105. <span>The Mind and Language</span>. MTuWTh 2-4. 4 units.<br></span></span></li>
</ul><h3>Session D (July 3-August 11)</h3>
<ul><li><span></span><span><span>R1B. Endangered Languages: What We Lose when a Language Dies<span>. MTuWTh 9-11. 4 units.</span></span></span><span></span></li>
<li><span><span></span></span><span><span>3. Linguistic Diversity. <a href="http://linguistics.berkeley.edu/~faytak/" rel="noreferrer">Matt Faytak</a>. MTuWTh 11-1. 3 units.</span></span></li>
<li><span></span><span><span>5. <span><span>Language and Linguistics</span></span>. MTuWTh 2-4. 4 units.</span></span></li>
<li><span><span><span><span>23 Language and Sex. MTuWTh 11-1. 3 units.</span></span></span></span></li>
</ul><p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Applying to UC Berkeley and Declaring the Major</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students who wish to attend UC Berkeley as undergraduates must apply to the University in November for the following fall semester. There is no application required for study in the Linguistics department. Application packets can be obtained in October from most California high school or community college counselors' offices, from any UC campus, or by contacting the Office of Undergraduate Admission and Relations, 110 Sproul Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720-5800, (510/642-3175). The application also is available on-line. <a href="http://admission.universityofcalifornia.edu/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer">Go to the University of California admissions site</a>.</p>
<p>All transfer students must meet UC eligibility requirements and the College of Letters and Science "Essential Skills" requirements for admission. Information is available at <a href="http://admissions.berkeley.edu/transferstudents" rel="noreferrer"><span style="color:#0066cc">http://students.berkeley.edu/admissions/transfer.asp</span></a>.</p>
<h2>Declaring the Linguistics Major</h2>
<p>To declare the Linguistics major, it is necessary first to complete Linguistics 100 with a grade of "C" or better and then submit the <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/advmajordeclaration.pdf" rel="noreferrer"><strong>"Major Declaration Petition"</strong></a> <strong> </strong>to the Undergraduate Student Advisor in 1205 Dwinelle Hall. Most students who petition for the Linguistics major do so in their junior year.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

</div><!-- /.boxton -->

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Careers</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Linguistics major provides a good variety of career possibilities. Linguists with BA's are frequently hired to teach foreign languages, English as a second or foreign language, and literacy. Employment opportunities also are available in such fields as health services, speech technology, legal consulting, writing and editing, language teaching, data mining, lexicography, and translation. Specialization outside the major (in language teaching, communication services, journalism, computational methods, psycholinguistics) is likely to enhance employability in these areas. Those wishing to continue to graduate school with a Linguistics BA from Berkeley will find themselves competitive for PhD programs in Linguistics and, depending on the focus of their major, in Anthropology, Psychology, Education, Sociology, and other fields. Berkeley BA recipients often continue to graduate school for professional degrees, as well, in areas such as speech language pathology, information management, library and information studies, accounting, museum studies, neuroscience, and law. Linguistics majors do well in the job market and in graduate school because of their skills in writing, critical thinking and interpersonal relations that are highly valued by employers and that apply to a wide variety of professional jobs.</p>
<p>Some representative job titles of recent Linguistics major graduates:</p>
<ul><li>Voice recognition analyst</li>
<li>Equity analyst</li>
<li>Bilingual first-grade teacher</li>
<li>Legislative assistant</li>
<li>Interpreter</li>
<li>Librarian</li>
<li>Actor</li>
<li>Marketing manager</li>
<li>ESL instructor</li>
<li>Production artist (with advertising agency)</li>
<li>Public relations manager</li>
<li>Brand name analyst</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Pre-approved Major Electives</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Courses Pre-approved as Electives for the Linguistics Major and Minor:</p>
<h3>AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDIES</h3>
<p>AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDIES 242  Special Topics in African Linguistics (Needs faculty approval each semester.)</p>
<h3>ANTHROPOLOGY</h3>
<p>ANTHROPOLOGY 166 Language, Culture and Society  </p>
<p>ANTHROPOLOGY 169C Research Theory and Methods in Linguistic Anthropology</p>
<h3>CELTIC STUDIES (Administered through the SCANDINAVIAN DEPARTMENT)</h3>
<p>CELTIC STUDIES 102A Elementary Breton<br>CELTIC STUDIES 105A Old and Middle Irish<br>CELTIC STUDIES 161 Celtic Linguistics</p>
<h3>EAST ASIAN LANGUAGES</h3>
<p>CHINESE 161 Structure of Chinese Language<br>CHINESE 165 History of the Chinese Language<br>CHINESE 167 Chinese Dialectology</p>
<p>JAPANESE 120 Introduction to Classical Japanese<br>JAPANESE 160 Introduction to Japanese Linguistics: Grammar<br>JAPANESE 161 Introduction to Japanese Linguistics: Usage<br>JAPANESE 162 History of the Japanese Language</p>
<p>KOREAN 160 Korean Linguistics</p>
<h3>DUTCH</h3>
<p>DUTCH 107 The Structure of Modern Dutch<br>AFRIKAANS 150 Languages and Cultures of South Africa</p>
<h3>ENGLISH</h3>
<p>ENGLISH 101 The History of the English Language (Needs faculty approval each semester.)<br>ENGLISH 102 Topics in the English Language (Needs faculty approval each semester.)<br>ENGLISH 179 Literature and Linguistics</p>
<h3>FRENCH</h3>
<p>FRENCH 145 History of the French Language<br>FRENCH 146A/B Introduction to French Linguistics<br>FRENCH 147 Special Topics in French Linguistics<br>FRENCH 173 Linguistics and Literature</p>
<h3>GERMAN</h3>
<p>GERMAN 103 Introduction to German Linguistics<br>GERMAN 105 Middle High German for Undergraduates<br>GERMAN C109/L&amp;S180T Language and Power<br>GERMAN 170 History of the German Language<br>GERMAN 173 The Phonetics and Phonology of Modern German<br>GERMAN 174 The Morphology and Syntax of Modern German</p>
<h3>INFROMATION, SCHOOL OF</h3>
<p>INFORMATION 159 Natural Language Processing<span style="color:#203866"></span></p>
<h3>NEAR EASTERN STUDIES</h3>
<p>CUNEIFORM 100A/B Elementary Akkadian<br>CUNEIFORM 101A/B Intermediate Akkadian<br>CUNEIFORM 102A/B Elementary Sumerian<br>CUNEIFORM 103A/B Intermediate Sumerian<br>CUNEIFORM 106A/B Elementary Hittite</p>
<p>EGYPTIAN 100A/B Elementary Egyptian<br>EGYPTIAN 101A/B Intermediate Egyptian</p>
<p>HEBREW 105A The Structure of Modern Hebrew<br>HEBREW 106A Elementary Biblical Hebrew<br>SEMITICS 100B Aramaic</p>
<h3>PHILOSOPHY</h3>
<p>PHILOSOPHY 133 Philosophy of Language<br>PHILOSOPHY 134 Form &amp; Meaning<br>PHILOSOPHY 135 Theory of Meaning</p>
<h3>PORTUGUESE - Please see SPANISH AND PORTUGUESE</h3>
<h3>PSYCHOLOGY</h3>
<p>PSYCHOLOGY C124 Psycholinguistics<br>PSYCHOLOGY 143 Language Acquisition</p>
<h3>SCANDINAVIAN</h3>
<p><span>SCANDINAVIAN 100A or 100B </span>Intermediate Scandinavian Languages (Danish, Norwegian, Swedish)                      <span>SCANDINAVIAN 101A Introduction to Old Norse                                                                                                              </span>SCANDINAVIAN 180 Socio-Historical Scandinavian Linguistics                                                                                      SCANDINAVIAN 201A Old Norse</p>
<h3>SLAVIC LANGUAGES AND LITERATURES</h3>
<p>SLAVIC LANGUAGES C137 Introduction to Slavic Linguistics</p>
<h3>SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIAN STUDIES</h3>
<p>SANSKRIT 100A/B Elementary Sanskrit</p>
<h3>SPANISH AND PORTUGUESE</h3>
<p>SPANISH 100 Introduction to Spanish Linguistics<br>SPANISH 161 Spanish Phonetics and Phonology<br>SPANISH 162 The Structure of Spanish<br>SPANISH 164 Spanish Dialectology<br>SPANISH 165AC Coexistence and Conflict: Amerindian, English, and Spanish in the Southwest<br>SPANISH 166 Language and Style<br>SPANISH 179 Advanced Course in Hispanic Linguistics</p>
<h3>UNDERGRADUATE &amp; INTERDISCIPLINARY STUDIES (UGIS)</h3>
<p>UGIS  120 Introduction to Applied Language Studies</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Honors Program</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>The department's honors program affords students the opportunity to learn how to put together a major research paper. It is necessary to have a minimum grade point average of 3.5, both overall and in the upper-division requirements for the major, to apply for admission to the honors program. The program consists of enrolling in 2-4 units in the Linguistics Honors (H195) course for 2 continuous semesters, normally in the student's final year. Under the direction of a faculty member, students carry out research and submit a thesis critically summarizing the material that has been covered. The deadline for submitting theses is the Monday of the 13th week of classes of the semester in which the thesis is submitted. Students who finish in the Spring semester will have an opportunity to present their research at a department colloquium at the end of the semester.</span></p>
<p></p>
<h3><strong><a href="https://lx.berkeley.edu/publications?topics=All&amp;pubtype=33&amp;order=field_openberkeley_pubs_pdate&amp;sort=desc" rel="noreferrer">ARCHIVE OF LINGUISTICS UNDERGRADUATE HONORS THESES</a></strong></h3></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

        <h2 class="block__title"><a href="/academics" class="active-trail">Academics</a></h2>
    
  <div class="block__content">
    <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
